Articles.Content:
Pardon the Noob post,

I am unsure if this is normal/standard for a startup, but while KSP is loading (at the loading screen) in the upper right hand corner, text(?) appears in varying colors, but most notable in orange with various statements that appear to be errors/problems. For example, while loading tonight one example would be that I noticed one text indicated that, "could not find a part module" in written in orange.

My question is if this is normal. As far as I can tell KSP appears to run/function fine (at least I can detect any issues/problems). 

 

Any help would be greatly appreciated.

 

I am running KSP 1.2.2.1622 on a 2017 iMac, 8 Gb Ram, GPU: AMD Radeon R9 M380 2048 Mb, CPU: 3.2 Ghz I5, OS X Yosemite.

I have acquired/installed the following mods via CKAN:

Stock assembly: Assembly-CSharp v1.0.0.0
ModuleManager.2.7.5 v2.7.5.0
BetterBurnTime v1.0.0.0
Chatterer v0.9.92.1622
MiniAVC v1.0.3.2
MiniAVC v1.0.3.2
HullCamera v0.3.0.0
IndicatorLights v1.0.0.0
InterstellarFuelSwitch v2.3.3.0 / v2.3.3
MiniAVC v1.0.3.2
Scale_Redist v1.0.0.0
MiniAVC v1.0.3.2
KerbalEngineer.Unity v1.0.0.0
KerbalEngineer v1.1.2.8
MiniAVC v1.0.3.2
ModularFlightIntegrator v1.0.0.0 / v1.2.3.0
Kopernicus.Components v1.0.0.0
Kopernicus.OnDemand v1.0.0.0
Kopernicus.Parser v1.0.0.0
Kopernicus v1.0.0.0
MiniAVC v1.0.3.0
PlanetShine v1.0.6121.34655
ReentryParticleEffect v1.2.0.0
TextureReplacer v2.5.4.0

 

"

Hi it''s not really normal, though i was unaware of any debug option that writes log messages on the loading screen, i do know of a mod that does, Exception detector , and it looks very much as you describe. That said the missing module will be just that , and a mod of some type is looking for it's other parts, in some mods there are add on parts that you don't need but will produce that little error if they are not installed.

A look at your KSP.log would show exactly whats going on and what could not be found
Please check your settings.cfg, LOG_ERRORS_TO_SCREEN is likely set to True, set it to False to disabled the on-screen error messages.
